Fundamental Limits on the Rate of Bacterial Cell Division

Nathan M. Belliveau*, Griffin Chure*, Christina L. Heuschen, Hernan G. Garcia Jane Kondev, Daniel S. Fisher, Julie A. Theriot, and Rob Phillips

Abstract

Recent years have seen a deluge of experiments dissecting the relationship between bacterial growth rate, cell size, and protein content, quantifying the abundance of proteins across growth conditions with unprecedented resolution. However, we still lack a rigorous understanding of what sets the scale of these quantities and when protein abundances should (or should not) depend on growth rate. Here, we seek to quantitatively understand this relationship across a collection of Escherichia coli proteomic data sets covering â‰ˆ 4000 proteins and 31 growth conditions. We estimate the basic requirements for steady-state growth by considering key processes in nutrient transport, energy generation, cell envelope biogenesis, and the central dogma, from which ribosome biogenesis emerges as a primary determinant of growth rate. We conclude by exploring a model of ribosomal regulation as a function of the nutrient supply, revealing a mechanism that ties cell size and growth rate to ribosomal content.

Work in Progress
